segments.text: I would like to see somebody, an anthropologist, really look at this influence of how our legal system, our judiciary system, our legislative system, which is totally related to the nature of the laws, which government is made of laws, not men, I take it.
but it nevertheless influences men and their way of thinking.
And there's really a tremendously fundamental inconsistency between our system of advocacy and science, and the manner in which advice, guidance can be exercised.
Of course, other political systems, and I'm just guessing it's Napoleonic ones of that nature, may not be quite so constrained.
All sides and all doubts and all questions and all levels of certainty can be discussed more freely in a system of that nature, perhaps.
So you see science as sort of an explosive institution where everybody puts in sorts of ideas and argues

and eventually you would affect, would you say, calculate risk, like you say the risk of a nuclear plant is 0.2% in terms of doing damage, so you ought to go ahead then and do what's necessary to develop one?
Is that fair to say, that sort of open debate?
I'm not a bit sure how the nuclear power plant business has gone, really.
I think that what has happened is that
Many companies developed nuclear power plants, and they were really looking for patentable aspects of them so that they could have control of them.
I know General Atomics had some very excellent parts of their development.
Somehow, all of this should be put together in the best parts of all of these put together, you see.
But that hasn't happened, I believe.
So each company has its weaknesses and its strengths.
What we need is the most certain sort of a nuclear power plant.

But if you want to talk about certainty and risk, and I truly believe that if in the brain of the archangel that runs this universe, there is some sort of a curve which says, what are the risks to the human race?
And the risks to the human race are not probably the ones we recognize, just exactly like the risks in war are very often not the ones we recognize.

And that if one really knew what this curve looked like and could make the product of risks and stakes, or on the positive side, risks are possibilities and advantages, it's the rare ones that are going to count, the very rare ones.
The fact that we can foresee you might have a nuclear accident is probably a trivial risk anyway.
If you multiply the stakes times the risk, it's a very low number.
On the other hand, there are a great number of other things that probably are not so.
Natural events.
And I truly think that science's role is to explore these more unlikely possibilities.
Let's look at the positive side for an instance.
There is no science that rules out the existence of a particle, which is a normal particle that has an opposite charge of gravity, just a negative gravity particle.
There's no law that rules such a particle out.
There is a rule that says if nothing rules it out, it probably exists.
What are the possibilities of such a particle existing and that we could make them?
A billion to one?
Maybe so.
But what are the advantages if we could?
Christ, an anti-gravity particle?
We'd be in real business if it were in normal manner, not animatic.
We'd really be in business, wouldn't we?
The boon to the world would be absolutely incredible.
The product of possibility and value is an immense one, even though it's only a billion to one or whatever it is.
The product is huge.
We must explore both on the positive side and the negative side these much more
outlandish, outre possibilities, it seems to me.

And we've got to think, and the anthropologists also, and the historians should really think about what are the risks and advantages that are critical to the survival of this species, which I take it is one of our principal concerns.
